member.name: T:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.Sensors.GeolocationAccuracy
member.summary: Represents levels of accuracy when determining the device location.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.Sensors.GeolocationAccuracy.Default
member.summary: Represents default accuracy (Medium), typically within 30-500 meters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.Sensors.GeolocationAccuracy.Lowest
member.summary: Represents the lowest accuracy, using the least power to obtain and typically within 1000-5000 meters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.Sensors.GeolocationAccuracy.Low
member.summary: Represents low accuracy, typically within 300-3000 meters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.Sensors.GeolocationAccuracy.Medium
member.summary: Represents medium accuracy, typically within 30-500 meters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.Sensors.GeolocationAccuracy.High
member.summary: Represents high accuracy, typically within 10-100 meters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.Sensors.GeolocationAccuracy.Best
member.summary: Represents the best accuracy, using the most power to obtain and typically within 10 meters.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Maui.Devices.DisplayInfo.Density
member.summary: Gets a value representing the screen density.

remarks.para: The density is the scaling or a factor that can be used to convert between physical pixels and scaled pixels. For example, on high resolution displays, the physical number of pixels increases, but the scaled pixels remain the same.

In a practical example for iOS, the Retina display will have a density of 2.0 or 3.0, but the units used to lay out a view does not change much. A view with a UI width of 100 may be 100 physical pixels (density = 1) on a non-Retina device, but be 200 physical pixels (density = 2) on a Retina device.

On Windows, the density works similarly, and may often relate to the scale used in the display. On some monitors, the scale is set to 100% (density = 1), but on other high resolution monitors, the scale may be set to 200% (density = 2) or even 250% (density = 2.5).

member.summary: The Launcher API enables an application to open a URI by the system. This is often used when deep linking into another application's custom URI schemes.

remarks.para: If you are looking to open the browser to a website then you should refer to the API.
On iOS 9+, you will have to specify the LSApplicationQueriesSchemes key in the info.plist file with URI schemes you want to query from your app.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Maui.Storage.PickOptions.PickerTitle

member.name: P:Microsoft.Maui.Storage.PickOptions.FileTypes
member.summary: List of file types that file file picker should return.
member.remarks:
On Android and iOS the files not matching this list are shown in the file picker, but will be grayed out and cannot be selected. When the array is or empty, all file types can be selected while picking. The contents of this array is platform specific; every platform has its own way to specify the file types.
On Android you can specify one or more MIME types, e.g. image/png. Additionally, wildcard characters can be used, e.g. image/*
On iOS, you can specify UTType constants, e.g. UTType.Image.
On Windows, you can specify a list of extensions, like this: ".jpg", ".png".

member.summary: Provides abstractions for the platform specific secure storage functionality for use with .

member.name: T:Microsoft.Maui.Storage.SecureStorage
member.summary: The SecureStorage API helps securely store simple key/value pairs.

remarks.para: Each platform uses the platform provided APIs for storing data securely:

item.description: Data is stored in KeyChain. Additional information on SecAccessible at: .
Encryption keys are stored in KeyStore and encrypted data is stored in a named shared preference container (PackageId.microsoft.maui.essentials.preferences).
Data is encrypted with DataProtectionProvider and stored in a named ApplicationDataContainer (with a container name of ApplicationId.microsoft.maui.essentials.preferences).

remarks.para: NOTE: On Android devices running below API 23 (6.0 Marshmallow) there is no AES available in KeyStore. As a best practice this API will generate an RSA/ECB/PKCS7Padding key pair stored in KeyStore (the only type supported in KeyStore by these lower API levels), which is used to wrap an AES key generated at runtime. This wrapped key is stored in Preferences.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Maui.Storage.SecureStorage.GetAsync(System.String)
